awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: Corporate Law, Finance, and Productivity in Historical Perspective
awd_abstract_narration:
This research studies the legal and institutional foundations of industrial and financial development. The particulars of commercial, contract, enterprise, and corporate law can have major consequences for how firms are organized and financed, with repercussions for the pace and structure of economic development in a society. The investigators examine the case of the Russian Empire around the turn of the twentieth century, because it offers a combination of uniquely high quality data and a particular set of legal and financial characteristics, all of which make it possible to study the relationships among company law, finance, and firm performance in an industrializing economy. This project collects and analyzes the new dataset while training a large number of undergraduate research assistants in statistical and research methods. 

This project involves the collection and analysis of firm-level data describing Russian corporations before the October Revolution of 1917. The data collection is international in scope, drawing on original corporate charters, archival records of firms and financial markets, and a wealth of historical newspapers, government reports, and other materials culled from archives and libraries in the United States, Russia, and Europe. The new dataset links the legal rules governing individual corporations to their subsequent financial characteristics, productivity, and market valuations. The publicly-available databases generated as part of the project are of interest to scholars in diverse fields such as corporate law, finance, economic history, economic geography, industrial organization, and Russian history. The Imperial Russian setting not only offers data of uniquely high quality for a developing economy, but it also provides substantial variation in the legal structures of corporations and in the underlying financial and industrial conditions. This enables the econometric evaluation of causal hypotheses regarding how corporations were financed and how Imperial Russian legal and economic institutions functioned. Thus, this historical project speaks to the role that legal institutions, corporate governance, and finance play in the process of economic development. The project's findings are salient for understanding the historical context of current legal and economic conditions in the Russian Federation, an area of current U.S. policy concern. This research involves undergraduate research assistants at every stage. These students learn methods of data coding, acquire skills in estimating econometric models, become conversant with a broad and interdisciplinary scholarship, and gain experience working with Russian-language sources. Mentoring undergraduates aligns with goals of both principal investigators' primarily undergraduate institutions.

por.por_cntn:
This grant has funded the collection and analysis of firm-level data describing Russian corporations before the October Revolution of 1917. Our project began with four central goals: first, to compose several datasets describing Imperial Russian corporations, including a database of annual financial information for 1900-1914 and a database describing how those corporations were governed. We also aimed to link this information to existing databases describing how those corporations performed on stock markets and how they performed as manufacturing establishments. Second, we aimed to compose a series of economics and economic history journal articles that evaluate hypotheses about the governance, financing, and performance of these corporations.  As a third goal, the project hoped to disseminate these results to related scholarly communities. Finally, because the project was conducted at primarily undergraduate institutions, the project aimed to train undergraduate research assistants in the tools of economics and economic history research. This outcomes report describes how we have accomplished each of these central goals.

First, we have completed a database of annual financial information on Russian corporations and are in the process of finalizing a new database on governance information for several thousand Imperial Russian corporations. We plan to make these new databases available through our project site (https://sites.google.com/williams.edu/russianhistoricalcorporations/home). We have also linked this information to market valuations provided by the St. Petersburg Stock Exchange Project (https://som.yale.edu/centers/international-center-for-finance/data/historical-financial-research-data/st-petersburg), and we are making progress linking our data to outcomes for manufacturing establishments provided by Gregg's Imperial Russian Factory Database (https://doi.org/10.3886/E110681V1).

Meanwhile, the information from these new databases has allowed us to compose several new articles on Imperial Russian corporations, one of which is published:

1.     Amanda Gregg and Steven Nafziger. "Capital Structure and Corporate Performance in Late Imperial Russia." European Review of Economic History 23.4 (2019): 446-481.

2.     Amanda Gregg and Steven Nafziger. "The Births, Lives, and Deaths of Corporations in Late Imperial Russia" was issued as Bank of Finland Institute for Economies in Transition Discussion Paper 26 (2020) and is currently under revision at The Economic Journal.

3.     Amanda Gregg and Steven Nafziger. "Financing Industrial Corporations in a Developing Economy: Panel Evidence from Imperial Russia" is currently under revision at the Financial History Review. This article was issued as Bank of Finland Institute for Economies in Transition Discussion Paper 7 (2020) under the title "Financing nascent industry: Leverage, politics, and performance in Imperial Russia."

4.     Amy Dayton, Amanda Gregg, and Steven Nafziger. "Shareholder Democracy under Autocracy: Voting Rights and Corporate Performance in Imperial Russia," issued as European Corporate Governance Institute Finance Working Paper 773/2021.

Over the course of the project, I have presented our work at several dozen seminars and conferences, including the NBER Summer Institute, the Economic History Association Annual Meeting, the Oxford All Souls Economic History Seminar, the Caltech Economic History Seminar, and the Northwestern University Economic History Seminar.

Finally, the project has had several important professional development outcomes. Since beginning the project in 2017, I have trained nine research assistants, who worked on the project part-time during the academic year or full-time during the summer.  Several of these students are pursuing graduate work in economics or political science, and one of them (Amy Dayton) is now a co-author of one of the project's articles.

As we have progressed through accomplishing the goals of the project, we have obtained several new and important findings. First, we have shown considerable variation in the financial strategies employed by Russian corporations, which we can rationalize through an understanding of the relevant institutional and historical context as well as standard results in modern corporate finance. Second, in our examination of Imperial Russian corporate dynamics, we find that Russian corporations evolved within a market environment, conditional on overcoming distortionary institutional barriers to entry that slowed the emergence of these leading firms in the Imperial economy. Further examination of Russian corporate finance in a panel setting reveals that asset tangibility was associated with lower debt levels, suggesting that Russian corporate debt was short-term, collateral was largely irrelevant, or agency problems dominated. We find that many of these same issues, for example, ownership structure and access to securities markets, also mattered for financial performance and that dividends may have compensated investors for poor legal protections. Finally, in our examination of Imperial Russian corporate governance, we find that overall, Russian corporations employed highly graduated voting rights and that less-graduated voting rights were associated with poorer performance.

We expect these new results to be of interest to a broad set of scholars in economics, finance, political science, and economic history. They may even have policy implications for the regulation of industrial corporations in low-income countries.
